In mid®February* when the new NAEB Journal editor. Dr. Colby Lewis, met with your
committee chairman and I to talk about the Journal. we discussed, among other
things, the availability of a series of articles ©a "personalities" in the field
of educational broadcasting and also articles of a historical nature. These
have both been suggested from time to fcima by various readers as areas of in¬
terest for the Journal.
We would like your help in several ways:
1. Names of such "personalities" who would be good topics for articles-®
and also suggestions for authors.
2. Your thoughts (pro or con) on such a series, with attention to some of
the following, raised by Colby: Are we saluting our senior citizens at
a time whan they are safely beyond the unfocused struggle of everyday
operations? Or am we singling oiit those who are still in there fighting?
How "colorful" must they be? Do we need to approve or disapprove their
efforts? Do we try to "explain" these people? Do we simply designate
someone close and presumably respectful and sympathetic to write them
up? Or do we collect the opinions of several persons who have interacted
with them and put these opinions together at the rewrite desk?
3. Suggestions of important nillastones in the development of educational
broadcasting that might make good "historical" articles--with suggestions
of surviving participants who might write about the evoivemeat of such
* milestones.
We would appreciate your help.
